Definition: The input contains an argument and a keypoint on the topic "We should ban human cloning", separated by "<sep>".Your task is to answer if the keypoint matches the argument and summarizes exactly what the argument means, in the context of this topic.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Human cloning should be banned as there is insufficient research into what might happen in the future with mutations, disease and genetic defaults being replicated.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unnatural
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that human cloning should be banned as there is insufficient research into what might happen in the future with mutations, disease and genetic defaults being replicated.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Human cloning is vital for medical science as it might be able to identify treatments and cures for diseases<sep>Keypoint: Cloning promotes science/research
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that human cloning is vital for medical science as it might be able to identify treatments and cures for diseases

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Human cloning should be banned because we don't know what the long term health effects are for a human being.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is not understood enough yet
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that human cloning should be banned because we don't know what the long term health effects are for a human being.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: We should ban human cloning because it raises too many legal questions regarding ownership and identity.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unethical/anti-religious
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that we should ban human cloning because it raises too many legal questions regarding ownership and identity.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Human cloning goes against nature and should be banned.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is not understood enough yet
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that human cloning goes against nature and should be banned.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Human cloning goes against nature and should be banned.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unnatural
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that human cloning goes against nature and should be banned.

Argument: Cloning might allow us to reproduce body parts such as livers, hearts, etc to help save lives of those who are desparately ill.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used to create more advanced humans
Argument: We shouldn't ban human cloning because it can lead to a perfect human race without flaws<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used to create more advanced humans
Argument: The cloning of humans could help us get the cures we need and the most appropriate treatments for certain ailments<sep>Keypoint: Cloning helps those who can’t otherwise have a child
Argument: Human cloning can be used to help find cures for, and prevent, hereditary diseases.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used to create more advanced humans
Argument: If we ban cloning we will not advance in science because we will be stopping a very important discovery.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used for organ replication
Argument: Human cloning should be banned because it interferes with nature<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unnatural
Argument: Human cloning provides a wonderful opportunity to test theories on health and medicine and should be encouraged not banned.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used for organ replication
Argument: Human cloning can lead to discoveries that could cure some of the most fatal illnesses we have.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning promotes science/research
Argument: Human cloning should be banned as it unnatural and there is no firm basis that displays the benefits that it can bring<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unsafe
Argument: It could help lead the way to find a cure for certain diseases<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used for organ replication

Argument: Human cloning demonstrates how far our technology has advanced. it may lead to such wonders as being able to generate organs for transplantation, which can only be a positive thing.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used to create more advanced humans
Argument: Human cloning can provide huge breakthroughs in the medical field.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used for organ replication

Argument: Human cloning is a huge ethical grey zone. we have no idea how this technology might affect someone's life, and the questionable moral involved shouldn't be messed with.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unethical/anti-religious

Argument: We shouldn't ban human cloning because it can help save people that might need organs, so having a transplant wont be a long waiting list.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used for organ replication
Argument: Copying something tends to weaken the original product and human cloning could cause defects that have never been seen before.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unnatural
Argument: Human cloning can lead to discoveries that could cure some of the most fatal illnesses we have.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning helps those who can’t otherwise have a child
Argument: Human cloning can enable scientific research into genetic disorders, possibly paving the way for life-saving breakthroughs.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning promotes science/research
Argument: Human cloning is unethical and not how we were created<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is not understood enough yet

Argument: Cloning of organs can and will save many lives, people who need organ transplants could be saved by cloning organs for them rather than waiting for others to die, cloned limbs would also help disabled people.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used for organ replication
Argument: Because it's unethical and unnatural<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unsafe

Argument: Human cloning is an experimental and untested area of science where the effects on those cloned is as yet unknown and could be life-threatening in a number of ways<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is unethical/anti-religious

Argument: By trying to clone humans scientists are trying to play god. experimenting on humans and trying to duplicate them could lead to consequences we can not even predict today.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is not understood enough yet
Argument: Human cloning must be prohibited because it could be used in many things to commit crimes<sep>Keypoint: Cloning is not understood enough yet
Argument: Human cloning is the future of medicine. cloned bodies and parts will save thousands of lives.<sep>Keypoint: Cloning can be used for organ replication
